awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Assessing the effects of complex developmental environments on fitness across lifespans
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. This fellowship will support work in integrative organismal biology as well as discipline-based education research in undergraduate courses. The biological research conducted through this fellowship will examine the role of the environment in shaping the development of organisms. By examining the nurture half of nature versus nurture, this research will illuminate how complex, ever-changing aspects of the environment shape an organism’s evolutionary fitness. The educational aspect of this research will be directed at improving equity and efficacy in undergraduate STEM courses at University of Colorado Boulder. Both of these research aims will produce scholarly works that will represent novel contributions to the respective fields. 

The two overarching goals of the organismal biology research are: (1) to assess the long-term effects of moisture and temperature individually on fitness using a modeling approach to analyze existing empirical data and (2) conduct further empirical studies on the interactive effects of moisture and temperature on phenotypes, behaviors, and fitness. The brown anole lizard (Anolis sagrei) will serve as an excellent system for this research, and this work will fill a significant gap in the understanding of this important model organism. Additionally, this fellowship will allow the fellow to build on their existing skill set as a field ecologist by incorporating new techniques that will make the research truly integrative in nature. The fellow will also improve their skills as an educator by examining teaching practices in higher education. This research will provide data that can shape future instructional techniques that will close performance gaps for marginalized student groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This award allowed the PI to make significant progress in the proposed biological research, educational research, career training, and mentorship of undergraduate and graduate students in research across disciplines. At the University of Colorado Boulder the PI started the fellowship in a new lab, which gave her the opportunity to actively participate in all of the practical and administrative processes required for starting a new research group. This process included planning, budgeting, purchasing, organizing and setting up animal care spaces for research, acquiring proper institutional approval for research, and all of the proper federal, state, and local permitting for animal collection. This provided invaluable experience for the PI as preparation for a career in academia. 

Following this process, the PI was able to complete the proposed work on developmental plasticity in reptiles. Reptiles are very sensitive to their environments, particularly during developmental stages, and thus serve as excellent study organisms for understanding the potential effects of the developmental environment across their life span. The prairie lizard (Sceloporus consobrinus) is a lizard species local to the University of Colorado Boulder, and an excellent system for these types of studies. After setting up a colony of adult prairie lizards, the PI conducted an experiment with a "2x2" temperature by moisture design (two temperatures and two moisture levels) where eggs produced by the colony were allocated to one of the four treatments to incubate until hatching. Upon hatching, data were collected on survival, body size, and behavior. Data from this experiment are set to be analyzed as a part of a herpetology course and submitted for publication.

The PI was also able to complete work in the field of education research. One such study surveyed students in an Animal Behavior course to assess their attitudes towards team teaching. Team teaching (a single course taught by multiple professors) is a common practice in higher education, but very little is known about how students view their practice or how they believe it affects their experiences in a course. The PI surveyed students in the course and interviewed instructors about their approach to the course and data from this study will be submitted to a peer-reviewed journal. Additionally, the PI was able to collaborate with education researchers at other institutions to write a review and prospective on the importance of incorporating Idealogical Awareness (IA) into Biology curricula. Incorporating IA materials in Biology classrooms would involve communicating the ways in which ideologies and their inherent biases and assumptions influence scientific outcomes. These materials have been shown to improve the sense of belonging for students historically left out of scientific work. This article represents a call to action and a foundation from which to build a more inclusive and equitable pedagogy. 

Finally, throughout the fellowship period, the PI was able to spend significant time improving both teaching and mentoring skills. The PI had the opportunity to mentor multiple students, both graduate and undergraduate, and guide them through summer research, senior and graduate thesis preparation, and applying to jobs and graduate programs. One undergraduate mentee was able to complete an independently designed research project that was synergistic with the PI's research that is currently in preparation for submission for publication in a peer reviewed journal. This was one of the most valuable outcomes for the PI's career training and went a long way towards preparing her for a career in academia. Through the experiences provided by this fellowship, the PI was able to secure a tenure-track faculty position while contributing novel work to the fields of biology and education. 


Last Modified: 12/26/2023
Modified by: Jenna E Pruett
